contentrichtext.text: {{ infobox cocktail | name = Shirley Temple | image = Canadia-style Shirley Temple.jpg | caption = Shirley Temple with lime garnish | type = nonalc | flaming = | garnish = [[Maraschino cherry]] | drinkware = | ingredients = [[Ginger ale]]<br/>[[Grenadine syrup]] | prep = | notes = | footnotes = }} {{Refimprove|date=December 2012}} [[File:Shirley temple.jpg|thumb|Shirley Temple in tall glass minus cherry garnish.]] A '''Shirley Temple''' is a [[non-alcoholic mixed drink]] made with two parts: [[ginger ale]] and a splash of [[grenadine]], garnished with a [[maraschino cherry]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Drinks Mixer |url=http://www.drinksmixer.com/drink1923.html |title=Shirley Temple recipe |publisher=drinkmixers.com |date=2010-01-01 |accessdate=2012-05-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Recipe Tips |url=http://www.recipetips.com/recipe-cards/t--1814/shirley-temple-traditional.asp |title=Shirley Temple - Traditional Recipe |publisher=recipetips.com |date=2012-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Food Network |url=http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/shirley-temple-recipe2/index.html |title=Shirley Temple Recipe |publisher=foodnetwork.com |date=2012-01-01 |accessdate=2012-05-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=CD Kitchen |url=http://www.cdkitchen.com/recipes/recs/59/Shirley_Temple59225.shtml |title=Shirley Temple Recipe from CD Kitchen |publisher=cdkitchen.com |date=1995-01-01 |accessdate=2012-05-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=CD Kitchen |url=http://www.thatsthespirit.com/en/drinks/recipe.asp?recipe_id=2403 |title=That's the Spirit! > SHIRLEY TEMPLE (non-alcoholic) Recipe |publisher=thatsthespirit.com |date=2009-01-01 |accessdate=2012-05-29}}</ref> Modern Shirley Temples are made with [[Lemon-lime|lemon-lime soda]], which is occasionally substituted in part, or in whole, for [[ginger ale]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Colleen Graham, About.com Guide |url=http://cocktails.about.com/od/s/r/shrly_tmpl_cktl.htm |title=Shelly Temple (Non-Alcoholic) |publisher=Cocktails.about.com |date=2010-04-08 |accessdate=2010-04-21}}</ref> Shirley Temples are often served to children dining with adults in lieu of real [[cocktail]]s, as is the similar [[Roy Rogers (cocktail)|Roy Rogers]]. The cocktail may have been invented in the 1930s by a bartender at [[Chasen's]], a restaurant in [[Beverly Hills]], [[California]], to serve then child actress [[Shirley Temple]]. Other claims to its origin, however, have been made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Sep/28/ln/hawaii709280385.html|title=The Honolulu Advertiser|accessdate=2007-09-28|work=The Honolulu Advertiser}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Hawaiian cuisine]] [[Category:Non-alcoholic mixed drinks]]
